summary: Formation of Bonds in GChemPaint tutorial, covering bond formation, system requirements, stereochemistry, and resources.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a title slide introducing the topic "Formation of Bonds," featuring a gradient background transitioning from green to beige. It includes credits for the script and narration by Madhuri Ganapathi and animation by Udhyaya Chandrika from IIT Bombay, dated 27 June 2013. The slide also provides links to educational resources: "Talk to a Teacher" and "National Mission on Education through ICT." The next slide outlines the "Learning Objectives," stating that the viewer will learn to add bonds to existing bonds, orient the bonds, and add stereochemical bonds. Following this, the "System Requirement" slide specifies the need for Ubuntu Linux OS v 12.04 and GChemPaint v 0.12.10. The final slide lists "Pre-requisites," indicating familiarity with GChemPaint chemical structure editor is necessary. Throughout the video, the background remains consistent with a gradient effect, and the IIT Bombay logo is visible in the bottom right corner. The text is presented in a clear, legible font, with key terms highlighted in different colors for emphasis.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio starts with a friendly greeting, leading into an instructional tone as a female speaker introduces a tutorial on bond formation in JChemPaint. The speaker outlines the tutorial's learning objectives, which include adding and orienting bonds, adding stereochemical bonds, and inverting wedge hashes. Technical details about the software version and the Ubuntu Linux OS are provided, alongside a note about the prerequisite knowledge of JChemPaint. The speaker suggests visiting a website for relevant tutorials if needed.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a molecular structure diagram of ethane (H3C-CH3) with a double bond between the two carbon atoms. The interface appears to be a molecular modeling software, featuring a toolbar on the right side with various tools and options for manipulating the molecular structure. The properties of the current element, carbon (C), are displayed, including bond length (207.0) and bond angle (120.0). The cursor is positioned near the diagram, indicating potential interaction with the software. The environment suggests a digital workspace, likely used for educational or research purposes in chemistry. The video maintains a static view of the screen, focusing on the molecular structure and the software's interface without any significant changes or movements.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a female speaker announcing the opening of a new ChemPaint application and its focus on ethane structure. She proposes to explore the conversion of saturated hydrocarbons to unsaturated ones in an instructional tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a chemical structure editor interface. The interface features a toolbar on the right side with various drawing tools and options for adjusting bond lengths and angles. The main area of the screen displays a chemical structure with two ethyl groups (H3C-CH3) connected by a single bond. The cursor is seen interacting with the structure, highlighting and selecting different parts of the molecule. The text "Current element: C" indicates that the carbon element is currently selected, and the properties panel shows the bond length and angle values. The video demonstrates the process of editing and manipulating the chemical structure within the software.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a female speaker instructing to copy and paste an ethane structure twice on the display area. She maintains a clear and informative tone throughout. She goes on to explain how to use selection tools, copy and paste functions, and move overlapping structures. She then shifts to describing the visible single bond between carbon atoms in the structures.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a chemical structure drawing program. The program interface features a toolbar on the right side with various tools for drawing and editing chemical structures, including options for adding bonds, changing bond types, and adjusting properties such as bond length and angle. The main area of the screen displays three ethane molecules (H3C-CH3) arranged horizontally. The cursor is positioned over the central molecule, indicating an interaction with the software. The program's status bar at the bottom reads "Ready," suggesting that the software is prepared for further input. The video captures the process of modifying the chemical structure, with the cursor moving and the central molecule being altered, likely to demonstrate the software's capabilities in editing and visualizing chemical structures.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single, calm, and steady female speaker describing the process of converting a single bond to a double bond, mentioning phrases like "add a bond" and "double bond". She explains the reduction of hydrogen atoms and identifies the resulting structure as ethene. There are no other sounds in the background.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a chemical structure drawing program. On the left side of the screen, three chemical structures are visible: ethane (H3C-CH3), ethene (H2C=CH2), and propene (H3C-CH=CH2). The right side of the screen features a toolbar with various drawing tools and options, including a dropdown menu for selecting elements, bond length, bond angle, and a checkbox for merging with existing atoms. The cursor is positioned near the propene structure, indicating potential interaction with the software. The environment is a typical computer desktop with a white background, and the atmosphere is focused on chemical structure visualization and editing. The video does not show any people or significant visual changes between frames, maintaining a consistent view of the software interface.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single, female speaker who narrates instructions on a scientific topic, likely related to chemistry, with a calm and informative tone. She describes converting "the single bond to a triple bond," detailing actions like clicking on an existing bond and observing the conversion and the reduction of hydrogen atoms. The narrator then introduces "ethyne" as the new structure.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a chemical structure diagram with three different types of hydrocarbons: ethane (H3C-CH3), ethene (H2C=CH2), and ethyne (HC≡CH). The interface includes a toolbar with various drawing tools and options for adjusting bond length and angle. The cursor is seen selecting and editing the ethyne structure, with the text "Ethyne" appearing below it. The environment is a digital workspace, likely a chemistry software program, with a clean and organized layout. The video focuses on the process of editing and labeling chemical structures, highlighting the functionality of the software.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a female speaker instructing someone to "write the names of the structures". She then guides the listener to "click on add or modify a text tool" and "click below the structures". The speaker follows up by instructing to "enter the names of the structures" listing "ethane", "ethene", and "ethyne".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a chemistry-related diagram featuring three chemical structures labeled "Ethane," "Ethene," and "Ethyne." The diagram is set against a white background, with the chemical structures arranged horizontally across the screen. The labels are written in a bold, sans-serif font, with "Ethane" and "Ethene" in black text and "Ethyne" in green text. The chemical structures are depicted using black lines and symbols to represent bonds and atoms. The screen also includes a toolbar on the right side, containing various drawing and formatting tools, such as lines, shapes, and text styles. The toolbar is organized into sections, with icons for different tools and options, including a dropdown menu for font styles and sizes. The video captures the screen in a static state, with no visible movement or changes in the content displayed.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a female speaker introducing "tetrahedral geometry" and suggesting to move the structures to the side. She then instructs to "press control A to select all objects" and click on the "select one or more objects tool" and drag the structures. The speaker speaks in an instructional tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "Structures," featuring a diagram of the tetrahedral methane structure. The diagram shows a central carbon atom (C) bonded to four hydrogen atoms (H), with bond lengths labeled as 1.09 Å and bond angles marked as 109.5°. The background is a gradient of green and beige, and the slide includes the name "Madhuri Ganpathi" and the phrase "Formation of Bonds" at the bottom. The scene then transitions to a 3D model of the methane molecule, with the carbon atom in black and the hydrogen atoms in white. The model rotates to display the molecule from different angles, emphasizing the tetrahedral geometry and bond angles. The background remains a gradient of green and purple, and the bond angles are labeled as 109.5° in blue text. The video concludes with the 3D model highlighting the central carbon atom in red and the hydrogen atoms in green, with the bond angles clearly marked.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female voice describing the tetrahedral methane structure, mentioning bond lengths and angles in a clear and informative tone. Following this explanation, a sound is perceived, but its nature is uncertain.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a molecular modeling software interface. At the top of the screen, three chemical structures are labeled: Ethane (H3C-CH3), Ethene (H2C=CH2), and Ethyne (HC≡CH). The interface includes a toolbar on the right side with various tools for drawing and modifying molecular structures, such as adding bonds, changing bond types, and adding or modifying atoms. The cursor is seen interacting with the software, first selecting a bond tool and then drawing a bond between two points on the screen. The bond length and angle properties are displayed in a pop-up window, with values set to 207.0 and 120.0, respectively. The cursor then switches to the hydrogen atom tool, indicating the intention to add hydrogen atoms to the structure. The environment is a typical computer desktop with a white background, and the atmosphere is focused on scientific and educational activities related to chemistry. The video progresses as the cursor continues to interact with the software, adding hydrogen atoms to the molecular structure, demonstrating the process of building a molecule within the software.
events_list.audio_caption: A female speaker starts by initiating the process of drawing a tetrahedral ethane structure. She instructs the listener to "click on add a bond", "orient the bond", and create three bonds, emphasizing a "tetrahedral geometry." The speaker guides the listener on how to attach hydrogen atoms by pressing "capital H", and selecting "H", clarifying that the hydrogen atom should appear in the toolbox. Finally, she prompts the listener to "click on all the positions to add hydrogen atoms."

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a molecular structure diagram of ethane, with the chemical formula H3C-CH3 labeled above it. The diagram features two carbon atoms connected by a single bond, each bonded to three hydrogen atoms. The interface includes a toolbar on the right side with various drawing tools and options, such as lines, arrows, and shapes, indicating that the software is likely used for creating or editing chemical structures. The cursor is seen hovering over the diagram, suggesting interaction with the software. The background is plain white, emphasizing the diagram and toolbar. The video progresses with the cursor selecting a tool to add a bond to the structure, and a pop-up window appears, displaying properties such as bond length and angle, with the option to merge with existing atoms. The overall setting is a digital workspace focused on chemical structure visualization and editing.
events_list.audio_caption: A female speaker begins by introducing the addition of stereochemical bonds to an ethane structure. She proceeds to describe the stereochemical bonds available in the toolbox, including the wedge bond, hash bond, swiggle bond, and four bond. The speaker suggests using the wedge bond to convert ethane to a stereochemical structure. The speaker then provides further instructions to click on the wedge bond tool and click on all the bonds. Finally, the speaker instructs to observe the changes and click on the hash bond tool before clicking on the display area.

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a molecular structure diagram of ethane (H3C-CH3) with its chemical formula and name labeled above it. The diagram features a central carbon atom bonded to two hydrogen atoms on each side, with additional hydrogen atoms attached to the carbon atoms. The interface includes a toolbar with various drawing tools and options for adjusting bond length and angle, as well as a properties panel showing the current element (hydrogen), bond length (207.0), and bond angle (120.0). The user interacts with the software by opening the "GChemPaint Preferences" window, which allows customization of themes, padding, and other settings. The video highlights the user's ability to modify the appearance of the molecular diagram through the preferences menu, with the "Invert wedge hashes" option being selected. The environment is a typical computer desktop with a focus on the molecular diagram and the software interface, emphasizing the educational and interactive nature of the application.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female speaker introducing and explaining "invert wedge hashes" using a clear and instructional tone. She describes how to access the relevant settings within a program's menu, specifically mentioning the "edit menu" and "preferences" window. She explains that the "invert wedge hashes" checkbox, when checked, will cause "wedge hashes bond will follow the usual convention" with "narrow end is at the start" and "broad end is at the other end". The speaker details how this setting impacts visualization of the bond and that the default in "G Kemp Paint is inverse". She mentions it "is more consistent with the perspective rules". She describes to "observe the changes in the hash bond". She instructs the listener to click on "close button to close the window".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a molecular structure diagram of ethane (H3C-CH3) and ethene (H2C=CH2) with their respective chemical formulas. The diagram is set against a white background, with the ethane structure prominently featured in the center. The ethene structure is positioned at the top right corner, while the chemical formulas are displayed above each structure. On the right side of the screen, a toolbar with various drawing tools and options is visible, including a section labeled "Current element" with properties such as "Bond length" and "Bond angle." The bond length is set to 207.0, and the bond angle is 120.0. The toolbar also includes a checkbox labeled "Merge with existing atoms." The cursor is seen moving around the screen, indicating interaction with the diagram. The video maintains a static view of the molecular structures and the toolbar throughout, with no significant changes or movements observed.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a female speaker instructing someone to "change the bonds to add a hash bond in the ethane structure", her tone is instructional. She then commands to "click on add a hash bond" and then to "click on all the bonds". After this she asks to "save the file".

events_list.video_caption: The video showcases a computer screen displaying a molecular structure diagram of ethane and ethene, with the chemical formulas H2C=CH2 and H3C-CH3 respectively. The diagram includes a central carbon atom bonded to four hydrogen atoms, with bond lengths and angles specified as 207.0 and 120.0, respectively. The interface features a toolbar with various drawing tools and a 'Merge with existing atoms' option highlighted in orange. The user initiates a 'Save as' dialog box, selecting the 'cdeep' folder within the 'Documents' directory, and names the file 'Formation of bonds.' The video concludes with the user saving the file, returning to the molecular structure diagram interface.
events_list.audio_caption: A female speaker with an instructional tone begins by saying "click on save the current file icon." She continues to provide further directions, mentioning "save as dialog box opens" and "enter the file name as formation of bonds." The speaker concludes with "click on save button" and "let us summarize."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "Summary" that lists key points learned about the formation of bonds, including adding bonds to existing bonds, orienting bonds, adding stereochemical bonds, and inverting wedge hashes. The slide is presented by Madhuri Ganpathi, as indicated by the text at the bottom. The background is a gradient of green shades, and the slide features a logo in the bottom right corner. The video then transitions to an "Assignment" slide, which outlines three tasks: converting propane to propyne, drawing propane and butane structures, and showing stereochemical bonds. The background remains consistent with the previous slide. The final part of the video shows a computer screen displaying a drawing application with chemical structures of propane and butane, as well as a diagram of propane and propyne. The application interface includes various drawing tools and options, and the text "stereochemical" is visible at the top left corner of the screen. The video provides a clear and educational overview of chemical bond formation and related assignments.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single female speaker summarizing a tutorial, mentioning adding and orienting bonds, including stereochemical ones, and inverse wedges. She then introduces an assignment to convert propane to propine, draw propane and butane structures, and show stereochemical bonds, stating that the completed assignment should look a certain way. The speaker has a clear and informative tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "About the Spoken Tutorial Project," featuring a gradient background transitioning from green to yellow. The slide contains two bullet points: the first instructs viewers to watch a video available at a specific URL, which summarizes the Spoken Tutorial project, and the second advises that if viewers do not have good bandwidth, they can download and watch the video. The slide also includes a logo in the bottom right corner and the name "Madhuri Ganpathi" along with the topic "Formation of Bonds" at the bottom. The video then transitions to another slide titled "Spoken Tutorial Workshops," which provides information about the Spoken Tutorial Project Team. It mentions that the team conducts workshops using spoken tutorials, gives certificates to those who pass an online test, and provides an email address for more details. The slide maintains the same gradient background and includes the same logo and name at the bottom. The video concludes with a static image of the second slide, emphasizing the information provided about the Spoken Tutorial Workshops.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a female voice introducing the Spoken Tutorial project, summarizing its activities and providing contact information, spoken in an informative tone. A single male voice then concludes the clip by saying "So."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a slide titled "Acknowledgements" with a gradient background transitioning from dark to light green. The slide lists the Spoken Tutorial Project as part of the Talk to a Teacher project, supported by the National Mission on Education through ICT, MHRD, Government of India. A URL for more information is provided: http://spoken-tutorial.org/NMEICT-Intro. The slide also includes a logo in the bottom right corner and the name "Madhuri Ganpathi" along with the topic "Formation of Bonds" at the bottom. The slide remains static throughout the video, with no changes in the text, background, or any other elements.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a female speaker informing us that the spoken tutorial project is a part of the talk-to-a-teacher project. She continues by explaining that this project is supported by the National Mission on Education, adding that more information is available via a provided link. She then credits Udaya Chandrika with the animation. After this, a different female speaker identifies herself as Madhuri Ganapathi from IIT Bombay and says "signing off", followed by "Thank you for joining."
